Change has been successfully merged

For any new code Community is recommending to use using nlohmann-json instead of cereal library. 
Refer Review discussion in this commit for details.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/71387
nit: spelling
Done

What are the implications of us not having these persistent fields? Is the dump still useful? Should we start out with some sort of "invalid" defaults so it's clear there was an issue trying to deserialize the data?

the dump storage path looks like this
/var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/dumps/<dumpid>

The serial will be in 

/var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/dumps/<dumpid>/.preserve/serialized_entry.bin

Here, check whether the dumped in the folder name matches the dumped stored in the file. It is unlikely that those will be different

However, a sanity check should be done before updating the dump entry with serialized data.

Since vital information about a BMC dump is already in the dump filename, the dump will still be usable, but the originator ID, type, and start time will be missing.
Acknowledged
Delete the current file so we'll write a new one with the new version?
Not deleting because if at all a matching firmware installed this data can be used, and we cannot create a matching serial data because we dont have the data we serialized at this point of time.
ok, I see. If we were forced to update the version for some reason then we'd add some code here to gracefully transition to the new version.
Yes that time, need to add code to convert earlier version to current version
nit: be consistent with code below and call this entryPtr
Done
nit: add a @return
Done
I'd recommend against using CBOR unless you have a strong rationale for it.  JSON is larger but compresses and is human readable.  If you _must_ have a binary format, CBOR is an alright choice.
I thought binary was recommended. The number of entries in each file is limited, so will keep it as JSON, which is easier to debug
Why pass this if we're not doing anything with it?  `remove_all(dir)` also works.
But that throws an exception, right? here just want to remove if the folder is already created
A hint here (in comments) might be appropriate then.
Done

You can also do something like:

```
j.at("dumpId").get_to(stored_id);
```

For member variables this might be clearer (originatorId, originatorType, etc.).
Done

nit:

"The id ({ID_IN_FILE}) is not matching the dump id ({DUMPID}); skipping deserialization."
Done
nit: spelling
Done
Can we do just VERSION?
Done
nit: size_t?
Done

Why are we deserializing it after we've already constructed it?  Doesn't that mean we're sending out a signal for an object creation before we actually have all the values in it?  I think this should be re-evaluated.

Among the following required information
- id - Part of the dump file and folder name
- size - the size of the file
- end time/elapsed - timestamp in the filename
- status - Serialized only completed dumps so that they will be completed
- start time - from json
- originator id - from json
- originator type - from JSON

If we deserialize first, then an object will be created and then updated with other values from the filename. Currently, values from the filename are added first, followed by values from JSON.

Or create an entry with default values without emitting a signal and pass it to the deserialize, 
deserialize, pick and fill the values from filename and JSON and then emit signal?
Changed to second option

Ick.  A raw pointer?

I guess this doesn't violate the core guidelines since this is a "position" pointer of sorts.
Removed, now that is not needed
Not used this?
no because id is already populated while creating the entry, will mark this as unused, wondering why no warning
Adding an additional validation with id to check the right filename is passed.
Acknowledged
need a return here?
if open failed anyway it will fail in the write.. and throw an exception, in the catch we are deleting the folder.. or throw some error here?
eh, I don't think I care that much for something that will probably can't happen.  Up to you.
That is correct will return
Done
Hopefully you're aware but the difference between `at` and `operator[]` are the same as map.  I think this can throw an exception if the "version" isn't there.

uint32_t version = j["version"].get<uint32_t>(); or 
j.at("version").get_to(version); can throw exception because of different reasons right? I think this get<uint32_t>() will throw exception if there is a failure in getting uint32_t?

This can happen when the serialized file is not in the expected format, and an error will be logged that deserialization failed.
Acknowledged
I guess this isn't really more readable?  I thought you could `get_to(originatorId)` directly but maybe not...
moving back to [], is better right? less number of lines
Acknowledged
it is better to delete this file , incase not used or bad file.
yes this is corrupted file, it can be better to delete
Done
dump  .preserve path file?
yes will change
Done
